**Descriptions**

This course aims to raise students’ interest in the “island encounter” between indigenous peoples of Taiwan and foreigners who came upon the island in the 19th century. The assigned readings with introduce students to some important writings in English about the “impressions of Taiwan” in the 19th-century by American and European travellers, diplomats, missionaries, or naturalists. In the first half of the semester, we will read selected chapters from the collections compiled and edited by Dr. Douglas Fix and translated by Charlotte Lo, which is entitled “curious investigations: 19th-century American and European impressions of Taiwan” (2006). In the second half of the semester, each student will choose an English article and report on the issues/problems he/she encounters in the essay. Together we will explore the “island encounter” defined as such. Students will be expected to turn in a final term paper that investigates a certain issue in relation to the issue(s) under study.      

**Objectives**

To cultivate the reading abilities in historical documents in English

To enhance knowledge and interest in the said area of enquiry

To develop capacities in independent research

To work on the draft of a publishable academic paper

**Requirements**  
You are expected to come to class prepared! **Before** class, you should have done all readings, worked on the homework problems and you should be able to participate fully in the discussions.  
1) Attendance and Participation, 10%

2) Oral Reports, 30%

3) Midterm Literature Review, 20% (a short paper about 3-4 pages)

4) Final Term Paper, 40% (the final term paper about 10 pages) 

**Textbook**

The Chinese translation of _Curious Investigations: 19th-century American and European Impressions of Taiwan_ (《看見十九世紀台灣: 十四位西方旅行者的福爾摩沙故事》，台北: 如果，2006.) A xerox-copied bound paper copy of selected chapters from the book will be available at Zheng-de-heng (讚德行), the basement copy shop in the night market. Please purchase it on your own. (Please note all English materials are downloaded from the website compiled by Dr. Fix at “Formosa: Nineteenth Century Images.”)
